title: nasm download url dead
body:
Hi,

The nasm.us website is down so downloading nasm doesn't work. A fedoraproject.org link could be used instead.

### Expected Result

Spack to download nasm as a dependency to another package.

### Actual Result

```
==> Fetching http://www.nasm.us/pub/nasm/releasebuilds/2.13.03/nasm-2.13.03.tar.xz

curl: (7) Failed connect to www.nasm.us:80; Connection refused
==> Fetching from http://www.nasm.us/pub/nasm/releasebuilds/2.13.03/nasm-2.13.03.tar.xz failed.
==> Warning: Spack will not check SSL certificates. You need to update your Python to enable certificate verification.
==> Warning: Spack will not check SSL certificates. You need to update your Python to enable certificate verification.
==> Can not find version 2.13.03 in url_list
==> Error: FetchError: All fetchers failed for nasm-2.13.03-ftouqgekcfxqxtrjrup3yhwaejor57kn
FetchError: FetchError: All fetchers failed for nasm-2.13.03-ftouqgekcfxqxtrjrup3yhwaejor57kn

/usr/local/spack/lib/spack/spack/package.py:1025, in do_fetch:
     25                                     self.spec.format('$_$@'), ck_msg)
     26    
     27            self.stage.create()
  >> 28            self.stage.fetch(mirror_only)
     29            self._fetch_time = time.time() - start_time
     30    
     31            if spack.do_checksum and self.version in self.versions:

```

### Steps to reproduce the issue

```console
$ spack install nasm
```

### Information on your system

 1. Platform: CentOS7 Singularity Container
 2. Using spack:develop

The following link could potentially be used as an alternative although it's bz2 and has a different hash.

https://src.fedoraproject.org/repo/pkgs/nasm/nasm-2.13.03.tar.bz2/sha512/d7a6b4cee8dfd603d8d4c976e5287b5cc542fa0b466ff989b743276a6e28114e64289bf02a7819eca63142a5278aa6eed57773007e5f589e15768e6456a8919d/nasm-2.13.03.tar.bz2

A slightly related question, what's the easiest way to get a dependants list/tree for a package. I'm trying to install OpenFOAM and one of the dependencies pulls in nasm, so if possible I'll try and avoid that.
